comments.body: it looks based on the example below that that command is p  but the title suggests the command is p(print). I'd personally find it clearer if the  titles were things like "print command"  and "set a module value" etc.  Even 'print command' isn't clear to me. Based on the output it seems to print which task I'm on (p task) or print the args vs variables etc. What are all the options I can use?  the title suggest only task, task_vars, host, and result but the example adds task.args as well.
Yeah, that looks like an omission. Good catch.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +198,202 @@
``print *task/task.args/task_vars/host/result*`` prints information about the task::

    [192.0.2.10] TASK: install package (debug)> p task
    TASK: install package

comments.body: Some commends below ask for more clarity in titles and options for the debug commands, but as an optional approach, you could summarize the seven commands in a bullet list to say what each one does. Then maybe the titles used below would make more sense to the unwashed masses (aka me).
Good idea. I think I'll make it a table and include a column for "shortcut", to clarify the `p(print)` thing.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +167,171 @@
You can use these seven commands at the debug prompt:

.. table::
   :class: documentation-table

comments.body: fwiw it took me this long to realize the debug commands are u or update_task , for example.
That's not clear enough, then. I think the table is the way to go.

So if I use `free` then ``redo`` may execute after a different task in the playbook?  That's how it reads, but it feels like logically, if I use `free` then my ``redo`` should happen immediately since no other tasks should run while  the debugger is active...
Excellent question. I got clarification on this and will post an update.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +300,304 @@
If you use the debugger with the ``free`` strategy, Ansible does not queue or execute any further tasks while the debugger is active. However, previously queued tasks remain in the queue and run as soon as you exit the debugger. If you use ``redo`` to reschedule a task from the debugger, other queued task may execute before your rescheduled task.


.. seealso::
